p: This is an area, however, where the anthropological record is considerably rich. Hunting and hunters are classic ethnographic subjects (Lévi-Strauss 1963; Myers 1988; Radcliffe-Brown 1965 [1952]) and, in recent years, sites of theoretical innovation (Descola 1996; Haraway 1989; Ingold 1988; Mullin 1999). While hunting was once held as an enduring artifact of emergent human civilization—a lens through which to explain gender relations, psychological proclivities, social organization, and the like—for contemporary anthropologists, hunting represents a profound (sometimes even poetic) engagement with the environment.
